) is the capital and largest city on

and the second largest city in the world that is unreachable by road. It is a port city on the Avacha Bay and surrounded by high, snow-capped mountains and volcanoes such that one cannot see the horizon from any point in the city. This city of roughly 200,000 residents is the principal entry point for travelers visiting the peninsula and has a well-built tourist infrastructure to cater to tourists who wish to do anything from wildlife viewing to bear hunting to paragliding.

value: Winter view of Petropavlovsk's central port

Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky shares the same parallels as

, but is harsher climate-wise.  
In summer the daily temperatures happen to reach 25-30C. Rains are frequent at daytime with mists that occur in evenings. Winters are mitigated by the sea and are much milder than the rest of Siberia. 
Snow blizzards and cyclones bring warm temperatures to 0...+1C. The end of January and begining of February are frosty, often about -20C.
The closest analogues in climate are Alaska's
airport is 16 km from city border in
. Most visitors arrive on the Aeroflot flight from
, but S7 and Vladivostok Air offer a 3-hour flight from
(10,000 RUB). There is also a regular connection to

by SAT Airlines. The Aeroflot flight is on an A330, S7 and Vladivostok Air use A320s. 
Other possible destinations include
. Beginning in July 2012, service will begin to

on Vladivostok Air.

Bus #113 goes from the airport to the city center for 25 RUR; a taxi would cost about 500 RUR ($20).
Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky is the second largest city in the world that is unreachable by road. However, a handful of roads on the peninsula connect the city with its airport (in
) and with the closed city of Vilyuchinsk.

value: File:Petropavlovsk Kamcatskij Volcan Koriacky in background.jpg

Most things of interest within the city are located within a compact area that can be covered on foot. The central square Teatralnaya is a venue for all major city events. Out of the square are running up three main streets: Leninskaya, Sovetskaya and Partizanskaya. There are also cheap buses and minbuses operating fixed routes throughout the city, mostly along the main road (fare as at July 2011 was 16 Rubles flat fare, pay driver as you alight).

value: — the center of town is based around a statue of Lenin, nearby is a statue of Jean Francois de la Perouse who lead a round-the-world expedition which sank in 1787 en route to Japan from Petropavlovsk.

— excellent views of the city and bay as well as the "Monument of Glory" erected in 1882 in honor of the heroic defense of the city, outnumbered 3-to-1, against the British/French during the Crimean War in 1854.
— the oldest monument in Russia's Far East, built sometime between 1823-26 in honor of Bering, who founded the city
— erected by the British in 1913 in honor of Cpt. Clark who died shortly after departing Petropavolovsk during a round-the-world voyage in 1779.
Monument to Lt. A. Maksutov's Battery
— a reconstruction of the 1854 battery which was the most crucial in the defeat of the Anglo-French siege

are the closest to the city mountains of Avachinsky group which includes Avachinsky Volcano (2741m), Koryakskaya Sopka (3456m) and Kozelsky volcano (2190m). Avachinsky Volcano is common venue for annual climbing with optional MTB downhill for the crazy.
directions=Between Prospekt 50let Oktyabrya and Zerkalnaya st
content=Small church close to the Trinity church.

On the first weekend of September the city hosts the Festival of Bard songs.

value: Krasnaya Sopka (red hill) next to the city
open Wed-Sun 10-1 & 2-8, this museum focuses on the native peoples of Kamchatka, the history of Russians on Kamchatka, and the native flora & fauna.
has a large collection of rock/mineral samples from volcanoes around the world as well as lots of stock footage of volcanic eruptions.
is only 10 years old but it holds a large collection of Russian and native artists. Open hours 10-18 every day.

tells about history, biology and geographical habitat of salmon, one of the ancient fish on Earth, which was being caught and processed from the times of Neolith up to the third millennium. The museum operates on working days and needs a preliminary call (23-58-35).
Take a boat out on the Avacha Bay for great views, fishing, and whale-watching
Go bowling at the Hotel Petropavlovsk
Go skating in covered rollerdrom at Toporkova st.(47-10-57), plus concert hall.
Mountain skiing at "Krasnaya Sopka" within reach of 25 min. from Petropavlovsk hotel

Some shops accept credit cards, but acceptance is not widespread.  Most Bankomats (ATMs) limit cash withdrawals to either 6,000 or 10,000 Rubles - note that some will levy a 2% fee in addition to whatever your own bank charges.  As at July 2011 Rosbank, Gazprom Bank and Bank of Moscow did not levy a fee.  The Bankomat at the airport has a 20,000 Ruble limit, but charges 2%.

value: content=A good place to stock up on area maps
content=A place where a tourist can buy all necessary things for a trip.
Shaman, an ethnic store with a variety of memorable trinkets.
'Kamchatka  Souvenirs', a department in GUM, the Central Supermarket offers pictures of artists, videos, wooden and bone carvings.

Shamsa (Шамса) supermarkets are great for food and beverage.  The deli section sells useful snacks such as piroshki, syrnicki etc.  Credit cards accepted - there is a big branch just across the road from the Km10 bus station.
content=A place where you can find decent food, interior and exceptional number of beer. Occasional live music is a nice addition.
content=Same place as above to serve wine.
content=Gzhel-style interiors with 60 seats, banquet room for 20 persons, all located in hotel 'Petropavlovsk' are great for parties
content=Decent set lunch for 200 Rub, understandably busy.
content=Enjoyable and small place. There is always live music and parties.
content=Fusion of European and Japanese cuisines, hooka-lounge, lounge-bar, DJ in violet-grey neon room.

content=A budget Soviet hotel, looks awful from outside but rooms inside have been renovated and are very comfortable and excellent value for this part of the world.  Limited English spoken.  Excellent views.  Tour agency Vision of Kamchatka is based here.  Single rooms for 2550 RUR, credit cards accepted with no surcharge.
content=Three stars and probably the best choice after the Hotel Petropavlovsk. Rooms are below western standards, but the hotel has a central location.

content=The city's "premiere" three star hotel is slightly less centrally located then the Avacha, but has a better restaurant and amenities. Regardless of whether you stay here, this is a good stop for its ATM machines, if you can get them to work (if not, try Planeta shopping centre). English-speaking staff

Public transportation in Kamchatka is limited to buses. The main bus station is on Pobedy Prospect and offers daily services (in high season) to
. Be sure to get to the ticket office early in the morning. It opens at 8:00AM.
